at least has their own idea of what devops is you've undoubtedly seen that kind of infinity symbol there's a few
displays of it outside in some of the sponsor booths where we talk about planning our work and then building and
testing and then deploying and shipping it out to production so by the way I'm going to do this like

time so thanks everyone um so you've probably seen this right idea
build ship go to production and then learn from what's in production and the
ultimate aim of devops is just to get through this cycle as quickly as possible but as safely as possible right
there's no point pushing things out to production if every single time you do it it breaks
so the idea is to get it out the door as as quickly as possible Right
um why though I mean I've certainly worked in a whole bunch of companies where you know you do a release every
six months or every three months or something like that and it goes horribly that's fine because you've got 300
features that you're trying to push into this one release and they don't play nicely together no matter how much you've tested them
but you only have to do it every three months right and then you know you chip it on a Friday afternoon and everybody comes in on the weekend and you have
pizza and it's great fun um so why isn't that a good thing
well generally the faster you can do this stuff and the safer you can do this stuff the more frequently you can push
real features real valuable features out to customers but a little bit beyond that more frequently sorry you can push
these features out to customers and judge whether they are valuable more frequently
like there's a big difference in an organization between saying you know that feature I just worked on for the
last six months turns out the customers don't actually want that at all
um that's a job ending conversation right it's very different to be able to say that than to say yeah we that feature
that we've just started working on we put out a really early prototype and made it available to this customer who's
really nice to us and they're happy to try these things for us and they thought we're going in the wrong direction so
we're going to just pull it back and we'll work on it a bit more and work out whether it is actually valuable like you've wasted a much much shorter period
of time it's much cheaper to change direction as early as possible so if you can get that feature out the door in a
few days few weeks even like you know up to a month or something like that you
can get a much better idea of whether it's going to work for your customers and whether it's valuable and the data
supports this right you've probably seen a ton of slides that look like this potentially with all of these you know
trusted sources of information claiming that high performing software engineering teams produce much faster

github's uh octaverse thing up to you know the New York Times report it's

to provision that machine and then also to get the right dependencies on that

a software developer would have to do but it's changed a bit but there's also things like internal
